text: i'd like to introduce Paul Mara who's our deputy director at the Stanford Center for Professional Development he
will be introducing today's speakers eve thank you very much and uh welcome
to this uh webinar we're pleased to have you here today and we have two terrific faculty members it's my good pleasure to
introduce uh Bill Bernett who's a consulting assistant professor of mechanical engineering uh Bill is uh
been working in this domain for quite some time he's currently the executive director of design program and he
manages the undergraduate and graduate program in design at Stanford both the joint program between mechanical
engineering and the art department in those areas he received his BS and MS in
product design at Stanford and has worked professionally on a wide variety of projects ranging from award-winning
Apple portable computers to the Hasbro Star Wars action figures he holds a number of mechanical and design patents
and design awards for a variety of products including the first true slate computer in addition to his duties at
Stanford he serves on the board uh of D2M a product design consultancy DSON
Energy an alternative energy company focused on developing biomass gasification energy systems for
smallcale municipalities and advises several startups uh in uh really the
company and design strategy bill welcome to the session i also have the pleasure of
introducing Chris Gertis who's an associate professor of mechanical engineering in the design group and the
director of the center for automotive research at Stanford and the co-director of the center for design
research chris directs the design lab and is a co-founder of the center uh
affectionately known as cars um this is where Stanford is bringing uh automobile
uh companies such as Volkswagen Audi Toyota together with uh the best minds
in computer science and artificial intelligence and cognitive psychology to ask some really big questions like what
does it take for a car to drive itself or can texting and driving be made safe
um after his presentation I'm sure Chris would welcome the opportunity to en uh engage more affiliate members uh to his
research center uh so if you are interested in that please let us know or let Chris know um Chris's current
research focuses on the integrated design and control of mechanical systems the application of advanced analysis and
control techniques to ground vehicle design and specifically to cars the
areas of specific interest for Chris include advanced driver assistance systems vehicle diagnostics and control
using GPS and integrated design control of the combustion system now I'd like to
turn over the floor to Professor Bill Bernett bill thanks
Paul um I want to talk to you a little bit uh to set up Chris's talk about this thing we're calling design thinking uh
this is a quote from David Kelly who's the founder of our our new institute the dchool where we're doing this integrated
approach to teaching everyone at the university how to think like a designer david you'll probably also know is the
founder of IDO probably the the largest product innovation uh and strategic innovation um consultancy uh in the US
and he would and he's he and uh I and the design group uh really believe that the next generation of innovators and
business leaders need to be great design thinkers so if you look at the way we educate people at Stanford um there's
many many different sort of methods of thinking on campus if you if you worked in the humanities department you're
probably in a post-rational um deconstructionist thinking mode if you're in the business school you're
being taught business thinking which is really a method a very uh kind of quantitative method of looking at
alternatives and deciding which is the the better the A or the B maximizing around net present value or internal
rate of return or strategic significance to the organization we do a we are in the engineering school and we do a lot
of engineering thinking engineering thinking is um very rigorous you you know try to isolate a system bound it by
a series of equations isolate the known and unknown quantities and solve for the unknown but in a lot of problems um you
can't bound the system they're uncontrolled humans are involved too many subsystems are involved and we find
that in in problems like that problems that designers have been working with all the time because in design you never
know what you're going to get until you until you start and the answer is it's more of a sort of an art of discovering
the answer than it is trying to rationalize to an answer in design thinking we work on problems that are
poorly bounded and we build our way forward it's a different way of thinking
and so let me let me talk a little bit about that of course everybody has a process we have a five-step process that
starts with empathy and works all the way through you know an iterative process of prototyping but really design
thinking isn't so much about process as it is about something else this is a
quote um that a colleague over in the business school uh relayed to me uh Alan Mley who's the uh the CEO of Ford after
a number of attempts to turn Ford around that it was where it just sort of wasn't working and they were bringing in the
consultants and they were saying oh well your product development process isn't right you need five tool gates and then they went on and they tried that for a
while and nothing happened and they still had bad you know bad results and then they brought in another consultant said oh no no no you needed seven tool
gates you know the process is the important thing finally ran into a young engineer in the break room who put up a
sign that says culture eats process us for lunch and and the point of this was
really that if you don't have a car culture and Ford had lost its way around
having a car culture a place where people just love to come to work and build the best car they knew how to
build and they had sort of devolved into a process-based culture with focus groups and everything sort of moving to
the middle when you have a when you have a process a tool gate version of process
and you need something like that we're not arguing that you don't need that but if you have if you rely solely on
process you end up with results that are moved immediately to the mean to the middle and so Malle took this to heart
he said "We're going to change the culture the the most important thing I can do as the CEO is not talk about process but talk about culture." And he
changed Ford back to a culture where people love to come to work and build great cars and as you know Ford is
probably the more successful of the US auto companies for it so we think it's about culture as well we think it's
really about creating a culture what we call a culture of creative confidence if
you want to unlock innovation in an organization people have to be free to be creative and creative people um act
differently than people who are working inside a process um they tend to break rules they tend to do things they're not
supposed to do um and they tend to act uh in a way that um allows them to
express their own sense of self and ego and once you've got that sort of a culture going lots of really interesting
things happen the other thing is we we start as you saw in the process slide um
we start with what empathy we start with a deep dive into the latent needs of the
user community that we're working with and that's not the same thing as market research market research is very
important so the macroeconomics of your of your market how many people are there how fast is the market growing things
like that but that doesn't tell you what people really need and you have to go
out and you have to be in their environment and study them and we use the tools of ethnography and cultural
anthropology it's a kind of a mashup of a lot of radical collaboration we bring anthropologists with us we bring
sociologists with us and we go out in the field and we ask people questions
now people can't tell you what they need necessarily no one can tell you "Oh I I need a smartphone that looks cool and is
easy to use and then voila you've invented you know an iPhone 4." But um
they can show you what they can show you and they can tell you what they're struggling with and what the problems
are and if you focus on needs we're going to talk a little bit about um the new emerging behaviors and needs in the
car when when Chris talks you can you can generally um come up with some really startling insights about where
the new opportunities are in your market or uh in the product
space certainly a culture of ideas we spend a lot of time at Stanford um educating uh our young engineers on how
to have better ideas now you think these these these uh these young students who are very very bright you know half of
the class is validictorians at Stanford the other half are have perfect SATs and such would be very good at having ideas
but in fact their education has been almost entirely leftrain right math
science and verbal and not so much on the right creative intuitive um big
leaps visual thinking so we we have a a class called me 101 visual thinking Um
and we have many other ways of sort of re-engaging their creativity so that
they can feel confident that they can have hundreds of ideas the typical um
engineering thinking is to look for the one right answer in design we look for hundreds of right
answers it's also a culture of radical collaboration and that's something that Chris is going to talk more about but
what's interesting about this this image here is you see uh five people sitting around on some red couches red couches
are sort of the um you know adopted symbol of the D school uh we went down
to IKEA one day when we didn't have any money and bought a bunch of couches and now they've turned out to be uh the
symbol of this new uh big international institution but what you see sitting on this table is something you would never
see in any other department at Stanford or sitting around this table um the gentleman in the far back left with the
gray hair Bernie Roth is one of the top um kinematics professors in the world also um a a designer and um uh an
educator on the on the front right is Terry Winrad one of the top AI
scientists computer scientists a uh human computer interaction uh people in the world and the woman with the big
smile Tina Sullig uh runs the entrepreneur program in the management science and engineering department so
you've got three completely different departments three senior professors all sitting around the table collaborating
on designing a new class um and you you would never see that happening at any
other part of the university the typical um model for educating everywhere else
is one professor with one subject matter teaching you know uh one thing in a
lecture mode all of our classes are taught problem based learning style and these guys are cooking up some really
interesting wicked problems for the students to work on it's also a culture of prototyping
this notion that you can't know the future so you build your way forward you build yourself into the future by trying
small experiments that are low risk and are meant to fail but are going to provoke new answers and kind of collapse
the boundary conditions of the problem around some very specific um examples of
what the future might look like and Chris will tell you more about that when he talks about the car projects
so I'm going through this quickly but just to give you a you know kind of a good sense or an overview uh design
thinking is a different way of approaching problems it's actually we spend as much time in the empathy um and
ideiation phase of design thinking finding good problems how often have you
in your organization worked really really really hard in a problem that you were either given by management or uh
you perceived to be the um the correct thing to work on only to discover after you had solved it that you were working
on the wrong problem that the real problem you need to really understand the problem you needed to zoom back and
understand more of the system and how the system uh worked together so we think the big leverage you get out of
design thinking and really what prototyping is all about is sort of searching for the right problem but it's also a way of framing
and forming new solutions which is different from analytic thinking we rely more on synthesis we look for the deeper meaning
inside a problem need finding is really not just about finding what are the use
and usability issues that people have with something why is it hard to use or how could you make it easier it's
actually really about finding out what what objects and and products mean to people and there's no richer area than
that and it's one of the reasons we're so interested in what cars is doing is that the the automobile has such a deep
cultural meaning in our society that the way the automobile is changing really reflects something about what uh
products mean and it's a very rich area for research so we rely on synthesis and meaning and context more than we do on
analysis or data reduction we employ creativity these creative problem solving methods empathy the cultural
anthropology and ethnography that research for the to find the hidden uh problem in the situation prototyping and
iteration and we do this multiddisciplinary radical collaboration process because that's what brings out
the sort of rich uh texture of the problem and we bring all of the stakeholders to the table together um
and there's this thing called wicked problems some guys at Berkeley a long time ago defined this thing an ill-defined problem which is messy
circular and aggressive and whose solutions are not true or false better or worse and also whose solutions once
you once you lock onto one solution you unveil the next level of the problem and
so these this is the kind of thing that design thinking loves to work on and it's quite effective we've we've had um
successful um companies launched out of our classes we've had successful problem solutions created in the classes we have
a whole series of case studies up on the dchool website that you can take a look at but I want to start um sort of
bringing this back over to um the uh a really wicked problem and that's you
know we've had automobiles in our lives well we've all had them for all of our lives but automobiles since you know the
turn of the century and probably there's never been a time when cars are changing more than they're changing now and and
you know it's a it's certainly a multid-disiplinary problem there's all the issues of you know making a vehicle
that's good transportation is comfortable to use but there's safety there's performance we have an energy
emerging energy crisis and our reliance on fossil fuels has got to diminish but we don't have effective high you know
density energy sources to replace them yet electric cars are okay but they're not quite there we've got all these
changing driver behaviors um uh you one of the things that um Paul mentioned in
the introduction that Chris is working on is you know can texting and driving be made uh compatible um it's
interesting i'm sure you know we've got a couple of hundred people uh logged on to the webinar i'm sure many of you if I
asked you have you ever texted while driving would in if you believed your
answer was anonymous if we were doing a poll you would say yeah I have and we all know that it's dangerous but we all
know it's a behavior that's emerged recently that's probably a need that's going to have to be fulfilled so how do
we solve that problem and then cars of course represent something in our culture and and who we are by you know
which cars we select the style with which we select them and the society in which you know we we choose to deploy
that persona so it's a fantastic uh uh uh test bed for the kind of design uh
methodology that we use and Chris is I'll turn it over to Chris now he is the head of the center for automotive
research at Stanford i think a lot of people don't realize that Stanford is is right now one of the really the centers
of this type of research in the world um people think of Stanford for microprocessors and bioengineering and
some other things but uh Chris's lab has really emerged as one of the leading um research um focal points and so uh I'll
turn it over to Chris to talk about the really wicked problem of designing the car of the future
great thanks a lot Bill um I do want the record to show that when I replied to your text message this morning I was in
fact stopped at a at a stoplight and not actively driving um I wanted to to kind
of build off of some of the things that you're saying unlike a lot of my colleagues in the design group I I don't do research in in design theory um what
we do however is what we say to try to have uh safe clean fun in cars um and so
I've got up there a couple of images from our research an advanced engine system that we're looking at for a new
type of combustion that could be uh much cleaner um on the left we have an
entirely studentbuilt electric vehicle uh which is designed to have uh steering
and throttle brakes all done by wire so we can actually customize the handling of that vehicle entirely in software and
on the right we have a car I'll talk about a little bit later an Audi TTS that we're turning into an autonomous
race car and we have approached these problems very much from the standpoint
of design thinking we have in fact created a culture of prototyping and as you can see we work with large amounts
of hardware now some of the students who join my lab have done this forever u one
had his own aftermarket auto parts company that he ran while he was uh in undergrad and some of them have ever
never actually wielded a wrench before in their lives and so what we do try to do is is create this sense of creative
confidence by having people work not only with the math but also with the actual cars you know and sometimes this
doesn't come smoothly the first time somebody who's very good at math goes and decides they're going to change the tires they end up stripping all the lug
nuts and we have to go replace those but lug nuts are replaceable and I think this sort of experience is is not uh so
what I wanted to do was to talk a little bit just a couple of examples from our research about how we've taken this sort
of larger idea of design thinking and applied it to produce some really tangible results both for us and for our
sponsors uh that led to some significant research advances so the first one I
want to talk about is is our P1 steerby wire car um and this has been the workhorse of our lab for a number of
years it was entirely studentbuilt so we had a team of five students that went from a clean sheet of paper to the first
moving test in about 15 months uh and as you can see there are certain things that we didn't do in that time frame we
ignored the rich Corinthian leather and the body panels and things like that but in fact the suspension the computers
everything has really been designed uh to perform at an extremely high level here uh we have independent front
steering so because we have a steer bywire system where we've separated the actual steering uh mechanically from the
driver we can turn the left and right wheel independently we can do an alignment on the fly we can in fact uh
snowplow the tires if we lose our brakes and do all sorts of things with that we have independent rear wheel drive so we
can actually steer it like a tank if we care to do that and there's been a huge number of research advances that have
come out of having this vehicle in our lab for the last 5 years we've learned some new things about how you can
stabilize a vehicle and prevent it from spinning we've learned how to actually estimate the friction between the tire
and the road before you're using all of it so your car in fact can know its limits and respond appropriately uh this
car will actually drive itself it will race itself around the track and we believe that it is the first vehicle
that is actually capable of drifting by itself so it can put itself into a sustained sideways drift and hold it for
an indefinite period of time not that we necessarily had a lot of competitors in this uh but but in fact we we feel we're
the first to uh to have done that now what's interesting is that this car has an has a history of starting as a
diagnostic project so in fact Nissan came to us and we had some discussions
about how to diagnose failures in these steerby wire systems if we no longer have a mechanical connection between the
driver and the steering system being able to make that safe and diagnose errors becomes absolutely critical so
Nissan came to us we discussed this and said "Well how about if you do a paper study to start?" And we said "Well no
actually we want to build a car." And so they reasonably asked why we wanted to build a car and I told them "I'm sure
we'll learn something." Uh at which point they asked me what we'd learned and I told them "We have absolutely no idea but it's going to be important." Um
so that that was sort of a a difficult thing to take but it was an outgrowth of our culture of prototyping we knew there
was something interesting there and we knew that we would learn it by building by getting students to have experience
with the entire system with a different perspective than you're likely to get in an automobile company so our partners in
crime here were Dave Beach and Craig Moy at the product realization lab and they're a larger part of this culture at
Stanford in fact they're they often say that if you walk into the product realization lab their job is to help you
build whatever you can envision so I went to Dave and Craig and said 'Hey we uh we want to build a car and not
knowing any better they said "Sure." Uh so we all launched off on on this project to build a car not really
knowing exactly what we were doing well along the way we had to design all aspects of this we had to design the
steering we had to design the suspension and since we were going to put students in the car we had to make sure that things weren't going to break so we
spent a lot of time thinking about what are the forces involved and we realize well the suspension has to of course
handle all the forces coming from the tires and the tires forces come from the vehicle motion so in fact our steering
motor is really feeling the vehicle motion like a trained race car driver our steering system knows by how much
torque it's applying by what the tire feels like exactly what's going on with the vehicle and we said hey wait a
minute this is an idea that we can do for diagnosis we can measure what the vehicle is doing how it's moving we can
measure what the steering thinks the vehicle is doing based upon this torque and we can compare the two there's a
comparison here that we can use to check to see if there's any failure in the steering system well we presented this
at a at a project review meeting and realized that there was a bit of a clash of cultures here so I have up a
schematic the specifics of this aren't aren't specifically important but our sponsors were responsible for the
electrical elements and the mechanical elements of the steer by wire system now as is typical when you have to do a
large project like an automobile it's important that the team has some focus and has some boundaries around what
they're considering so this was kind of the way the world looked to them their responsibility were for the batteries
the DC toDC converter that would allow them to run a motor controller the motor the sensors that they were going to use
to uh to actually figure out where the steering was at any given time and that
was their view of of the system and we came back and said well wait a minute there's a car here and in fact we can
measure what the car is doing and our systems level perspective is in fact broader we can use that knowledge to
have information go back and forth between what the car is doing and what the steering electronics are doing and
this originally seemed like a kind of a strange idea because if you understand electrical components they have a lot of
nice properties they're really fast they're easily modeled and they're fairly certain whereas the vehicle
dynamics themselves are much more complicated and subject to a lot of disturbances and noise how many people
do you have in your car did you throw the golf clubs in the back are your tires inflated are you driving in the
rain all of these things that make this connection difficult to understand so we
were in fact proposing that you take this wonderfully compact system that's
easily explained and by understanding its connection to this more complicated
more difficult to understand system there would be some value uh so at the end of a very long meeting where where
our sponsors fired questions at us had long discussions in Japanese fired more questions at us went back and forth I I
asked where they stood and and they said "Well we're skeptical but very interested." So we went ahead and built
this and as it turns out this was greatly successful we were able to diagnose faults that were below the
level of human perception so we could put somebody in the car they could drive we could introduce a small problem with
the steering system that they didn't even feel and as a result we were able
to then pull out and show them that the system had managed to to sense a small discrepancy despite the um the
uncertainty in the vehicle dynamics we could still use these sorts of techniques now this is a start of a
great cooperation with Nissan we had a variety of folks from Nissan come and drive the car this is a picture of uh
CEO Carlos Gon coming and taking the car out for a spin it's epitomized our
collaboration with Nissan we've just recently ended about a two-year stay of
a visiting researcher uh who came from Nissan and worked directly in my lab and really was a fantastic fantastic lab
member um so one of the things that has interested them is just our approach to problems the way that we're able to take
design thinking ideas and come up with very specific engineering innovations u
as a result of that so the second story I'd like to talk about is involving our
development of driver assistance systems so one of the ongoing questions that we have in the lab is how do we assist even
the best drivers in avoiding accidents and this is a a difficult problem
because in fact if you look at polls generally about 79 80% of people
consider themselves to be above average drivers um about 20 or so% consider
themselves average and usually get about 1% of people who feel that they need help and are below average drivers so if
we're going to make driver assistance systems how do we get past the idea that people feel that they don't really need
this sort of help and so our solution to this is to think about how could we assist even the best drivers and now how
do we do this well again consistent with our culture of prototyping with the idea of iteration asking questions our desire
is to build a car that drives like the very best drivers so on the right here I've illustrated our Audi TTS we've
offic a affectionately nicknamed the car Shelly after Michelle Muton who is the first woman to win the Pikes Peak Hill
Climb driving an Audi and our goal has been to use this project this whole idea
of can we design a car that can race itself around a track whether it be a dirt track or a paved track can we use
that challenge as a way of understanding how to support drivers so I have a brief
video of some of the testing that we've done on this car which I think shows a little bit about the the culture of of
how we do this um you'll see the the team out in the Bonavable Salt Flats and this was actual footage taken during
some of our

that gives you a little bit of a sense of of what it's like uh on the project uh those are scenes that we took when we
were out testing in the salt flats in fact the scene where the car drives off by itself with no one inside was the first time we had ever tried that uh
that was actually captured uh on on film we uh have a very special team working
on this and Bill mentioned radical collaboration uh the team that we have together on this project involves uh
faculty graduate students undergraduates at Stanford it involves engineers from Volkswagen and Audi and Oracle and we
were all together out on the salt flats uh testing the car the tents that it showed was in fact our our only shelter
on the salt flats for a period of about a week or two weeks as we go out and and do this sort of testing uh so it does
take a a very special group of of dedicated people uh to go out and test
in these conditions to work together as a team despite the fact that things are not working um and that's always
someone's fault right it's either the software that's not working or the hardware that's not working how do you get past that how do you work together
as a team that's one of the other things that we think we can learn from racing this whole analogy where you have to get
the car to perform out on the track everyone has to work together is a a beautiful way of of thinking about
teamwork about how you can execute the radical collaboration now beyond that
one of the things that we're learning from this project is where machines have an advantage over even skilled drivers
as we've attempted to reconstruct in some ways what human race car drivers do
we've learned some areas where where they have some advantages we've learned some areas where the computer has an
advantage and we think as we continue to dial in on these things we can really develop driver assistance systems that
will help even the best drivers that will do things that even the most talented race car drivers find to be
tremendously challenging and even those uh 80% or so of above average drivers on
the road would have great difficulty doing so from this project uh we're
already seeing how this gets into uh systems that can prevent accidents and we're reporting all of that information
back to our colleagues at at Audi and Volkswagen so that's a little bit about
what um what we do and the way that we do it and I think I guess we have a
break before questions right we'll uh we'll certainly be welcoming questions we've seen a few questions come in via
the chat function so feel free to uh consider questions for Chris and uh
we're going to turn it back over to Bill Bernett yeah uh I have a question for
you Chris um you know I saw in the video um the Audi doing these you know
four-wheel drifts spinning the um the Audi logo in the uh in the sand out
there was that were were those experiments that you had designed in advance or how did you dis how did you
decide what to do when you got out to the salt flats well that's a actually a really good
question um in putting together the video we had some ideas that that came in from actually the the video team
about things that that could be done and what was interesting was working together with the video team they said
you know it's it's actually not important whether the car can can do it itself we can just make it look like the
car is doing it itself and I said "No that that doesn't work at all we're a research group we pride ourselves on on
credibility there cannot be one thing that you show in the video that the car is doing that we haven't done
autonomously that we haven't done with the car uh itself and so as a result we we did things like you know they wanted
a scene where it shoots across the salt flats at about 130 mph." So we had itself we had the car drive itself at
130 mph across the salt flats that actually wasn't originally planned but they wanted to show it and so we got
that going uh they had the idea of sort of drifting the Audi rings which was a huge huge hit with our sponsors um that
that image has uh has has really been an enduring one from the from the project
and so we we developed the program to enable it to go and and drift the drift
the rings it turned out at the last minute when they did the helicopter shot suddenly we had to reverse the entire
pattern and so we literally with a helicopter in the air reprogrammed the
path to get the car to do it in the other direction uh changed all of the the boundaries and the markings and and
executed what you see there on the video so had you ever ridden driven the car at
130 m an hour before no that was new that was new okay that was new so in
addition to radical collaboration you need a little bit of radical uh courage it sounds like and um I also you you're
talking about um you know building cars that can do you know what the best drivers do and I know you mentioned the Pikes Peak Challenge um what's this
what's the status of of Shelly right now visa v the Pikes Peak Challenge well so
um last September we we did some preliminary testing there are huge logistical challenges to testing on on
Pikes Peak so Pikes Peak is a publicly open road they closed it for the hill
climb um and in fact we closed it for our testing so there are no other vehicles on there it's about a 12.4 mile
stretch of of switchbacks so part of it's paved uh part of its dirt and it
goes up to about 14,000 ft with with no guard rails and some sheer drop offs uh
so we wanted to make sure that we could get our position information from GPS that we would have reasonable enough
maps to to drive up there and so in September we went and we ran it with a lead vehicle and a chase vehicle just to
make sure that the the path was clear it is crisscrossed with hiking trails and we did occasionally find hikers uh
unexpectedly on the on the road and have to pause the test but with the lead and chase vehicles we ran it up and down um
six times uh without anybody in the car so we got a good understanding of what it takes to to run on Pikes Peak we've
been continuing to develop it um we were using a dynamics pad at Infinine uh just
about a week ago trying to see how close we are to the actual um theoretical limits of how fast the car can go and
then uh our plan is to continue to go on with uh with some testing on tracks and then once we get everything dialed in um
hopefully we can go back to Pike Speak and test it speed and I know you've been working with Professor Cliff Nass um on
some of the so sort of social issues and we mentioned texting and Cliff's Cliff's done a lot of research on multitasking
and texting and things can you talk a little bit about you know the car in society and this notion of autonomous
vehicles or just even autonomous machines and kind of the research um questions that you're looking at there
sure i think um one of the things that we've been establishing in our research
is what can we do what are the limits what are the possibilities that we can do with driver assistance systems and um
what what are the technical capabilities as we've established those it's become increasingly apparent that a lot of the
interesting questions are what should we do and as you go back and forth between cars where the driver is fully
responsible for everything and cars where the car is responsible for everything those are two easy concepts
to understand but one of the great challenges is how do you do anything in between how do you begin to get a car to
work cooperatively with the driver what sort of capabilities can you take away from the driver without having them tune
out of the driving process entirely and if we do start to support how do you
have the car and the driver understand each other the car has some perception of the environment it wants to take
actions that it thinks are safe how do you get that level of understanding across uh to the driver and there's some
very interesting theories out there uh in fact treating the autonomous vehicle like a horse um the understanding of how
you get these two intellects uh together to negotiate these sorts of of safety
issues and I think working with Cliff is a great example of radical collaboration he's approaching this from the
standpoint of human machine interaction from communications and being able to work together with with his students
which we do in a a driving simulator is is a great opportunity
thanks um Paul I think uh or Kissa we're going to turn it back to you for a moment and

um just uh hold on just a second so there we go so um we uh have a program

entrepreneurs the individual entrepreneurs are not as effective as pairs and pairs are the most effective

around entrepreneurship we know that teams of two are the best in terms of teams of sort of radical collaboration
teams teams that get larger in in any subgroup larger than five to seven it's

try to make the the boundaries between these different groups fairly permeable

know three to five people in any jazz combo they can see each other they can respond to each other immediately they

but they they are so good at their individual instruments they're so so good at their individual um professional

from the working on the same milestones that gives organization that's the and the conductor conducts that organization
but where you need breakthroughs and innovations and you may need it in multiple places you want to break your
